title-group.article-title: Impact of Expanded Medicaid Eligibility on the Diabetes Continuum of Care Among Low-Income Adults: A Difference-in-Differences Analysis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Internal Medicine, Boston Medical Center, Boston, Massachusetts
2Health Law, Policy and Management, Boston University School of Public Health, Boston, Massachusetts
3Hubert Department of Global Health, Emory University Rollins School of Public Health, Atlanta, Georgia
4Department of Family and Preventive Medicine, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, Georgia

author-notes.corresp: Address correspondence to: Lily D. Yan, MD, Department of Internal Medicine, Boston Medical Center, 801 Massachusetts Ave., CTC 2nd floor, Boston MA 02118. lilyyan@alumni.stanford.edu.

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: The impact of Medicaid expansion on linkage to care, self-maintenance, and treatment among low-income adults with diabetes is examined.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A difference-in-differences design was used on data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, 2008–2018. Analysis was restricted to states with diabetes outcomes, and non-pregnant adults aged 18–64 years who were Medicaid eligible based on income. Separate analyses were performed for early post-expansion (1, 2, 3), and late post-expansion years (4, 5). Analyses were performed from September 2019 to March 2020.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: In comparing expansion versus control states, low-income residents with diabetes had similar ages (48.9 vs 49.1 years) and proportion female (54.4% vs 55.0%), but were less likely to be non-Hispanic Black (20.8% vs 29.2%, standardized difference= –16.3%). In expansion states, health insurance increased by 7.2 percentage points (95% CI=3.9, 10.4), and ability to afford a physician increased by 5.5 percentage points (95% CI=1.9, 9.1) in early years, but no difference was found in late years. Medicaid expansion led to a 5.3–percentage point increase in provider foot exams in the early period (95% CI=0.14, 10.4), and a 7.2–percentage point increase in self foot exams in the late period (95% CI=1.1, 13.3). No statistically significant changes were detected in self-reported linkage to care, self-maintenance, or treatment.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Although health insurance, ability to afford a physician visit, and foot exams increased for Medicaid-eligible people with diabetes, there was no statistically significant difference found for other care continuum measures.
